title.narrative: Yes I do Ethiopia incl COVID-19 prevention

description.narrative: SUMMARY Millions of adolescent girls all over the world are facing a limited future because of early marriage (EM), teenage pregnancies and female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C). With this project, by changing the attitude of community members and other key persons and informing adolescent girls and boys, adolescents will be empowered to stand up for their sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Through education and economic empowerment, supported by the relevant legislation and policies, the project will give adolescents alternatives beyond EM, teenage pregnancies and FGM/C. The project will be implemented between 2016 and 2020 by Plan International Netherlands, together with partners Amref, Rutgers, Choice, KIT and the Netherlands Embassy in Addis Ababa and will be carried out in Kenya, Zambia, Malawi, Mozambique, Indonesia and Pakistan as well.

Deep-rooted norms and expectations of girls and boys makes families and communities feel the need to control the sexuality of girls by marrying them off and forcing them to undergo FGM/C. Gender inequality is putting girls in a subordinate position with regard to boys and men in (sexual) relationships. For example, girls cannot refuse to have unprotected sex and this is resulting in a high level of teenage pregnancies. Girls and boys lack a voice, as well as the support to break through these norms and practices. The means and structures available for adolescents to organise themselves are limited and they have little access to adolescent-friendly and good quality SRH information and services. There are close links between EM, FGM/C and teenage pregnancies and girls’ lack of education. Indeed, girls’ access to education is very restricted, which makes it difficult for them to find jobs later. It also hampers their economic independence. Legislation to outlaw FGM/C is either inadequate or is being poorly implemented.

EM, FGM/C and teenage pregnancies have similar root causes and these practices mutually reinforce one another. Social and gender norms are deeply embedded in communities and this situation can only be changed if community leaders and most of the people, including boys and men, support the change. Key persons in the communities, including boys and men, will be turned into allies in the process of changing these norms, thereby helping to address the problem of EM, FGM/C and teenage pregnancies. A general lack of information about SRH and poor quality and access to the relevant services are perpetuating the above-mentioned problems. Adolescent boys and girls are being informed about SRH and given a voice to claim this information and these services. Girls are being given more control over their lives. This is being achieved by changing these norms and people’s behaviour, strengthening networks and structures for social mobilisation and embedding these in communities, and by involving the government and the private sector in improving SRH and services. All these will help to reduce EM, FGM/C and teenage pregnancies.

This programme is a follow up of the Plan regional EM programme (18+) in Malawi, Zambia and Mozambique, in which adolescents are being trained as agents of change to make their voice heard in claiming their SRH. The programme is being implemented by the Yes I Do alliance in which each partner is adding value by implementing part of one or more of the intervention strategies. Ethiopia was selected based upon on-going programmes of the alliance partners on FGM/C, EM and teenage pregnancies in the respective countries.
Final beneficiaries are girls between the age of 12 – 24 years, married and unmarried.

Plan Ethopia focusses mainly on economic empowerment and education for girls ( pathway 4) with few community sensitization activities for an enabling environment under pathway 1. main activities: • Strengthen and support youth activist groups • Menstrual Hygiene Management at schools • Provide financial support and income generating activities for drop outs • Support girls clubs in school to create a safe and quality driven school environment. • Provide teacher training on Gender Responsive pedagogy
This will be worked out per country.

title.narrative: Children, youth or adults have skills to make changes to their lives
% girls aged 15-18 currently attending secondary school (Bahidar Zuirya) (pathway 4)

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in two intervention areas (Woredas: Bahirdar Zuirya and Qewete in Amhara Region). The survey included question about child marriage. We obtained a sample size of 1600 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. However- the political unrest impacted the administration of data collection- in Bahirdar Zuria nly 46% of the planned target- in Qewet it was possible to reach 100% target. This resulted in an overall coverage of 73% (1166 respondents) as compared to the planned target.

comment.narrative: % girls aged 15-18 currently attending secondary school (Bahidar Zuirya) (pathway 4)

title.narrative: % girls aged 15-18 currently attending secondary school (Qewete) (pathway 4)

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in two intervention areas (Woredas: Bahirdar Zuirya and Qewete in Amhara Region). The survey included question about child marriage. We obtained a sample size of 1600 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. A total of 1602 questionnaires were administered- which was the planned target.

title.narrative: Communities take charge of their own development processes
Number of initiatives in the local community and local clubs/associations/schools to address FGM, TP and CM and gender inequality

comment.narrative: Number of initiatives in the local community and local clubs/associations/schools to address FGM, TP and CM and gender inequality

Contrary to previous years where the # of trained community groups were counted, these are networks of community groups The networks took different initiatives to reduce and bring promising behavioural change towards on CM, FGM and GBV issues. For instance, the groups established in the flower firms influenced the firms management and then 6 flower firms revised their HR and incorporated GBV/gender issues as a policy. The trained groups also established a firm committee to be the voice of girls and young women working in the firm as well the members of the groups take initiatives/commitment not to tolerate case of GBV and report it on timely manner.
10 community conversation groups, 7 change agent groups, 7 youth activist groups

28 Community Conversation groups with 560 members (280 male, 280 female), 7 change agent groups, 15 youth activist gropus and 18 peer groups in local communities are created to address CM, TP and FGM and gender inequality
Girls clubs, Community counselling groups, SRHR clubs, mini media clubs, youth activist groups, peer groups, YID groups
28 CC groups, 15 Youth activist groups & 18 peer groups that were already established last year were strenghtened and actively performed awareness raising sessions including peer to peer dialogues
68 CC groups, 20 Iddir, 40 CoC and 10 Meharebe clubs,10 in-school girls clubs

68 CC groups, 20 Iddir, 40 CoC and 10 Meharebe clubs,10 in-school girls clubs Activities by these groups school based community members organized a school level campaign at Korebta kebele Salayish primary school and a total of 500 students including community members/parents (Female: 200 female) sensitized on child marriage and unsafe migration by school directors, club facilitator and kebele manager. • To act against HTPs (CM, FGM and TP) multi-stakeholder network is established at community level in 10 kebeles of Bahir Dar Zuria Woreda. The network is involved COC facilitators, CC facilitators, religious leaders, Iddir leaders, school principals, representatives of girls’ club kebele administrators • To capacitate and support the networks of CBOs, CSOs and nearby higher institutions aimed to advocate issues of SRH and promote gender equality a consultative meeting conducted with a CSO network named “Network for Action to Children, Girls and Young Women Empowerment’s” (NAGWE) which is established by 23 CSO working groups in Amhara Region with focus areas of child marriage, gender based violence and women economic empowerment. • Four events using March 8, Day of African child, world children day and women white ribbon day Issues of HTP particularly CM, FGM, TP as well as issues of vulnerable children and gender based violence were the main discussion agendas of the events. In those events, 795 (Female: 474) participants comprised from schools, youths, children and community members participated.

• school based community members organized a school level campaign at Korebta kebele Salayish primary school and a total of 500 students including community members/parents (Female: 200 female) sensitized on child marriage and unsafe migration by school directors, club facilitator and kebele manager. • To act against HTPs (CM, FGM and TP) multi-stakeholder network is established at community level in 10 kebeles of Bahir Dar Zuria Woreda. The network is involved COC facilitators, CC facilitators, religious leaders, Iddir leaders, school principals, representatives of girls’ club kebele administrators • To capacitate and support the networks of CBOs, CSOs and nearby higher institutions aimed to advocate issues of SRH and promote gender equality a consultative meeting conducted with a CSO network named “Network for Action to Children, Girls and Young Women Empowerment’s” (NAGWE) which is established by 23 CSO working groups in Amhara Region with focus areas of child marriage, gender based violence and women economic empowerment. • Four events using March 8, Day of African child, world children day and women white ribbon day Issues of HTP particularly CM, FGM, TP as well as issues of vulnerable children and gender based violence were the main discussion agendas of the events. In those events, 795 (Female: 474) participants comprised from schools, youths, children and community members participated.

title.narrative: Service providers respond to the needs and rights of children and youth
Number of schools where a Child Protection Policy is in place (pathway 4)

comment.narrative: Number of schools where a Child Protection Policy is in place (pathway 4)

17 schools (10 in Bahir Dar Zuria and 7 in Kewet) put in place child protection policy, safe and enabling environment for school children and adolescents girls. In addition girls’ advisory committees have been established, which comprised teachers, school girls and school principals, to advise and consult girls on social, economic, psychological and other issues like their educational performance improvement in and out of school environment. As the result girls in schools will be protected from any abuses both in school and their community and they will have better opportunity to report the cases and even cancel them.
10 in Bahir Dar, 7 in Kewet

title.narrative: Service providers are capable to deliver services that are sensitive to rights of children and youth and gender equality (C2)
Number of service providers that deliver on development objectives (indicate sample size)

comment.narrative: number of service providers (from government agencies, schools, C/FBOs and private sector) trained on key issues related to prevention and response to CM/TP

358 male and 173 female staff members trained: - members of COVID-19 task forces to integrate CM and SRHR messages - gvt and private sector staff on decent work and GBV at workplace - teachers on Gender Responsive Pedagogy - VERA/birth registration officials on improvement of birth registration - Woreda and C/FBO stakeholders on CM and unsafe migration These trainings were intensive and in most cases followed up by Plan and partner by further technical support
31 F and 3 M have gender responsive pedagogy skills
number of teachers who have increased knowledge on gender responsive pedagogy and SRHR issues

Number of service providers that received training on gender and child rights and that play an active role to change the social norms: teachers and woreda office experts, MFI and TVET staff and other service providers including health extension workers

48 teachers and woreda office experts, 7 MFI and TVET staff and 61 of various service providers inclulding health extension workers play an active role in the communities, in the schools and in the policy making to help improve prevention of CM, TP and FGM

comment.narrative: (Qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in girls indicating safety in and out of school is an issue
The study found no sufficient evidences about improvements in terms safety and security of girls.

So in the end the total of reached members exceeded the planning. Of the 838 trained, less than half were women.

title.narrative: Direct service delivery to individuals
Number of children, youth or adults who benefited from direct service deliveries

comment.narrative: Number of girls that are supported to continue school by direct financial support (82), provision of school materials and dignity kits (722) and through income generation suppport of their family households (80)

1667 school children (1313 girls and 354 boys) received school materials (total 650 in Bahir Dar and 1017 in Kewet); 84 girls received financial support to be able to continue their secondary education (28 in Bahir Dar and 56 in Kewet) and 69 households received income generation support through which 50 girls and 19 boys were able to continue school (total 19 in Bahir Dar and 50 in Kwet)
dignity kits ands scholastic materials
scholastic materials, financial support to boarding, sanitation pads
155 girls who received financial support to attend post primary education plus 2381 girls who received scholstic materials
900 girls who will receive scholastic materials including dignity kits to be able to continue school and 60 girls to support with boarding to be able to continue secondary education
850 girls received material items including dignity kits to be able to continue school, and 97 girls received boarding support to be able to continue secondary education

title.narrative: Capacity training for policy makers
Number of capacity trainings delivered to policy makers (specify)

description.narrative: Different kind of policy makers are targeted : of health sector, justice sector, gvt involved with private sector and VERA agency responsible for birth registration system

comment.narrative: Number of capacity trainings delivered to policy makers (specify)
Training of government staff members on child protection/GBV and decent work.

• In collaboration with BoWCYA and Bureau of Labour and Social Affairs, capacity building training provided for 39 (female: 5) participants comprised from government and (semi) private sectors ( Woreda Administrator, Investment office, Technical and Vocational Development office, Women, Children and Youth affairs office and flower farms). The training focused on GBV and decent work. • PIE in partnership with ECD organized a two days consecutive training on child protection issues for 72(Female: 19) government experts and FBOs leaders. The topics discussed during the training were CM, FGM, their legal frameworks, gender equality and how to build child protection systems and major strategies.

different kind of trainings: 1 for government officials who are involved with flower farm and other private sector on GBV; 1 for VERA agency on improving birth registration; 2 for different gvt agencies to increase knowledge on improving implementation of laws regarding FGM and CM

1 training was given for 15 government staff members on importance of measures against GBV in private sector companies. Two day workshop for 59 woreda and kebele duty bearers on the implementation of YIDA program and on issues CM, TP and FGM. Consultative workshop with 61 participants to enhance the knowledge and social behavior of key stakeholder on child protection issues, capitalize learning and linking among system of local governments, religious institutions, community structure; improve the child protection systems/ mechanisms and strengthen the documentation, monitoring and reporting of child protection concerns. Capacity building for 767 officials of different gvt and judiciary organisations on the importance of registration of vital events particularly birth registration to help prevent CM

The target is based on 40 Champions of Change clubs which will be set up in 2019; the existing youth activist group members will become part of these CoC clubs as well as newly selected youth members. Youth members will be in majority community based including out of school youth.

40 CoC clubs were set up and trained in the first modules. The youth activists who became member in the course of 2019 already were active in clubs and in 2019 held in total 147 peer to peer dialogue sessions and other community based awareness reasing sessions.

title.narrative: Dialoguing with communities
Number of dialogues between alliance local partners and communities, religious and traditional leaders

comment.narrative: Number of dialogues between alliance local partners and communities, religious and traditional leaders

800 Community Conversation group discussions , 800 Champions of Change discussions, 200 in Iddir discussions (1 meeting per month in 100 Iddir leaders/group) in the planned ten months of implementation in 2020

230 Community Conversation group discussions were conducted and a total of 1200 (Female: 600) CC members (adult) have acquired basic information on impact on GBV, Child marriage, girls education, advantages of gender equality as well as information on COVID 19 pandemic. In addition, 140 Champions of Change discussion sessions were conducted in which 1431 (female: 698) adolescents/youth members have participated and got awareness on gender equality and COVID 19 protection mechanisms. The session conducted in person keeping the procedures of COVID-19 prevention methods.
number of campaigns conducted on harmful impact of CM, TP and FGM
4336 adult community members participated of which 2121 female
Different sort of sessions including Community Consultations, specific gatherings etc. ; in total 2910 community members (1403 female) including religious leaders, iddirs etc took part.
number of community dialogue and peer to peer sessions by supported community groups (Community conversation groups, Iddir groups, youth activist/CoC groups) total for 2019

In total in 2019, 682 dialogues were held by the community groups (504 by Community Conversation groups, 178 peer to peer dialogues health by youth activist and COC groups. Less then planned because of delayed extra activities (COC implementation) funded by extra funds in 2019/20

title.narrative: Children, youth or adults are economically active
% of girls between 18 – 24 years old who are economically active outside of the household (Bahidar Zuirya) (pathway 4)

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in two intervention areas (Woredas: Bahirdar Zuirya and Qewete in Amhara Region). The survey included question about child marriage. We obtained a sample size of 1600 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. A total of 1602 questionnaires were administered- which was the planned target.

comment.narrative: % of girls between 18 – 24 years old who are economically active outside of the household (Bahidar Zuirya) (pathway 4)

title.narrative: Vocational, business and life skills training for children, youth or adults
Number of children, youth or adults who completed vocational skills trainings (pathway 4)

comment.narrative: Number of children, youth or adults who completed vocational skills trainings (pathway 4)
50 in Kewet, 30 in Bahir Dar Zuria
50 girls in Kewot and 29 in Bahir Dar Zuria have completed training on entrepreneurship and vocational skill training on animal fattening, poultry and animal rearing.
Total of 17 plus girls in 2018 targeted to receive vocational skills combined with business skills and entrepeneurial skills in a three-months training at local TVETs
Number of girls who finalized the training
Girls who dropped out of school and are about 17 plus to be trained in Bahir Dar, and Kewet. Content of vocational training differs, can be on animal raising, hairdressing, bakery

All girls selected for vocational training combined with business (economic) skills training completed their training. This is because the girls were selected on capability, motivation and other criteria and a match was made with their preferred trade.

title.narrative: Dissemination of information
Number of community members (adolescents) reached with information dissemination initiatives

comment.narrative: Number of community members (adolescents) reached with information dissemination initiatives
Total of adolescent boys and girls that are reached with information by Champions of Change, Community Conversation, Iddir groups and via other discussion groups as well as through campaings

1431 (698 female) adolescents reached via Champions of Change, 1250 via other groups like Community Conversation groups and via specific sessions organized by partner BCDO and 1950 boys and girls reached via other awareness sessions including national day events
